column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Finnish national parks
#Text=Finnish National Parks are found in most parts of the country .
#Text=In addition to national parks some other protected areas are presented below , as well as national hiking areas and the wilderness areas of Finnish Lapland .
#Text=Finland has a diverse nature , with forests , fells , mires , bogs , lakes and islands featuring in many of the parks .
#Text=In a few parks the interaction between Man and nature is a central theme .
#Text=As Finland is sparsely populated , one can often be alone with nature in the less known parks and in remote areas even of popular parks .
#Text=Understand
#Text=The parks are open to the public without any entry or hiking fees .
#Text=Many have services such as marked hiking trails , cottages , goahtis and saunas for rent .
#Text=The right to access is usually somewhat restricted in the parks , but the offered free services should compensate that for most visitors .
#Text=National parks and strict nature reserves are always on state owned land , but other protected areas may be on ground owned by other entities , even privately owned .
#Text=There are nature trails in most of the areas listed below .

#Text=In nearly all but the smallest areas , there are locations for rest ( with campfire sites and pit toilets ) and in the bigger ones hiking trails and some lodging facilities ( often lean-to shelters , in the north more commonly open wilderness huts , in popular areas also rental cabins ) .
#Text=Berry and mushroom picking is usually allowed , in regard to edible species .
#Text=Taking anything else from the nature is usually forbidden in national parks and nature reserves .
#Text=Dogs must be kept on leash with few exceptions ; you may see people letting their dog free , but even a friendly dog can wreak havoc , especially among nesting birds .
#Text=Information is usually available in English , but some ( such as most information boards along nature trails ) may be in Finnish only , or Finnish and either Swedish or Sami .
#Text=Most of the really large parks are in the far north , in the Sami native region .
#Text=Regulations of the parks try not to disturb the traditional livelihood of the Sami .
#Text=Thus e.g. reindeer herding , hunting , fishing , taking wood for own needs and even driving are often allowed for the locals also where forbidden otherwise .
#Text=The local population is sparse enough that this does not generally threaten the ecology of the areas .
#Text=National parks , hiking areas and wilderness areas
#Text=National parks are the prime destinations for those wanting to see Finnish nature other than normal countryside .
#Text=They are always on state owned land where the nature is deemed to be of general interest as a sight or for education .

#Text=As the national parks are always also nature conservation areas there are restrictions to the right to access : collecting stones , plants ( other than edible mushrooms and berries ) or insects is usually forbidden , wild camping is allowed only in certain areas and entry to some locations may be restricted .
#Text=Pets may not be kept loose .
#Text=Services , such as trails , shelters and campfire places more than compensates for this for most visitors .
#Text=Acquaint yourself to the rules of the park in question , especially if you are not just walking marked trails .
#Text=The parks are maintained by Metsähallitus , the Finnish forestry administration .
#Text=The national hiking areas are specifically for hiking and for acquainting oneself to the nature of the region , offering quite large versatile and at least seemingly unspoiled areas .
#Text=The nature may not be untouched but at least the forestry should be invisible for the trekker .
#Text=There is good infrastructure , such as hiking trails , campfire places and lean-to and cooking shelters .
#Text=Most hiking aseas have also accessible nature trails .
#Text=The right to access also usually applies .
#Text=The areas are maintained by Metsähallitus .
#Text=The wilderness areas were established in 1991 to preserve their wilderness character , the Sami culture and the Sami natural form of livelihood .
#Text=There are twelve such areas , all of which are located in Lapland .

#Text=The wilderness areas are not nature conservation areas and the right to access usually applies in full ( there may be local restrictions ) but on the other hand they are planned to stay wilderness so there 's very little infrastructure as well .
#Text=There are few services in these areas themselves but often tourist businesses nearby may arrange some service on request .
#Text=The wilderness areas usually lack any marked trails and therefore are of interest especially for experienced hikers who are used to making their own paths .
#Text=If there are some marked trails , they cover only part of the area .
#Text=If there are skiing routes in winter , only the markings are maintained , not the tracks themselves .
#Text=The areas are maintained by Metsähallitus .
#Text=These areas are all listed below .
#Text=Nature reserves and other areas
#Text=The selection below of nature reserves and other areas is somewhat arbitrary .
#Text=The ones listed are deemed to be of interest also to the casual visitor , some as a destination in themselves , some worth a visit if you happen to pass by .
#Text=Recreation areas are usually maintained by the municipality .
#Text=They may have good infrastructure like the national hiking areas , often also facilities for outdoor sports and sometimes camping sites and the like .
#Text=They are not listed here , but may be mentioned in the city articles .
#Text=The strict nature reserves are primarily for nature protection and research .
#Text=Visiting a strict nature reserve usually require a written permission from Metsähallitus , but some have trails inside them though .
#Text=Hiking is completely restricted to these marked trails at least during the warmer part of the year .
#Text=Larger reserves may have other infrastructure , such as pit toilets and shelters for rest and overnight stays ( often just outside the protected area itself ) .
#Text=As the right to access is severely restricted , you always should check the rules of the individual area .

#Text=Open strict nature reserves are mostly small , some suitable for a trip of a few hours , some for a weekend , but there are also bigger areas , an extreme being the Kevo strict nature reserve with a 64 km trail .

#Text=Entry to bird nesting areas is prohibited in the bird nesting season , but there may be towers for bird watching and trails and other service in the neighbourhood or in less sensitive parts of the area .
#Text=The seal protection areas may be closed for public year round .
#Text=There are also many areas for protection of specific types of nature or specific features of the nature , such as mire , old-growth forest and esker protection areas .

#Text=These typically have no restrictions relevant for visitors , other than on any land , but you should probably be careful about not causing erosion or wildfire and not to harm plants and wildlife .
